wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
I have been photographing people and places for over 40 years using both film and digital cameras. I have worked in studios, stock photo agencies and on a cruise ship. I now design & build mobile applications for a living whilst exploring the abstract and emotional potential of photography.

Education M.A. in Philosophy & Politics, University of Oxford B.A. in Photography, Polytechnic of Central London

Exhibitions Sutton Library, Surrey UK, 1984 Broad Street Railway Station, London UK 1986 St. Petersburg Biennial, Russia 1996 Soho Photo Gallery, NYC 2016.

I have been photographing for over 35 years. I always shot when traveling, from France to Mexico, the Galapagos to Thailand, Spain to India, but I always come back to New York, my home, and surrounding areas in New Jersey and Long Island for much of my subject matter. I shoot color the majority of the time. While most of my photographic journey has been with a 35mm film camera, shooting and scanning color slides, I have now fully embraced a 35mm digital camera.

Paul Stetzer has ended one career and begun another. His first profession was education, beginning in Head Start in 1968. He then became an environmental educator at an urban nature center and concluded as an elementary science teacher at Germantown Friends School. Along the way he did social work, he drove a taxi, and he helped to found an international union as well as much later an artists’ collective. After spending all his life in Philadelphia teaching and raising two daughters, he married his childhood sweetheart and moved to New York in 1997. It was then that he was introduced to the endless wonders of Cape Ann, and he hastened to focus his landscape work there. In New York City and Cape Ann he practices photography: landscape, portrait, and documentary. Paul’s documentary work includes assignments for the University of Chicago, United Neighborhood Houses, Career Transition for Dancers, City Harvest, and the Annie E. Casey Foundation. He is actively working on two projects: “Time and Tide In Cape Ann” and “Democracy is coming. . .” , images of people struggling for justice. Paul has studied with a number of superb photographers, including Phil Borges, Ellen Binder, Lina Bertucci, Steve Hart, and David Welles. His work has been exhibited in a variety of galleries in New York City as well as in Philadelphia, Vermont, Massachusetts, Florida, Mexico, and Cuba. In addition, Paul hosts internships and teaches classes in photography. He is an active member of the Soho Photo Gallery in New York City. He has volunteered his photography for a variety of not-for- profits as well as for aspiring actors, models, and singers.

Richard Gardner’s roots are grounded in beauty. Major influences include the celebrated fashion photographer Sarah Moon in addition to Surrealist artist Man Ray. For decades as a hairstylist, make-up artist and photographer, he has documented the perceived reality of beauty within the current zeitgeist. A self-taught photographer, Gardner has taken courses at both the International Center of Photography and the Center of Photography at Woodstock. His hand-colored images have been used as part of the course curriculum at ICP. In addition to his fine art work, Gardner accepts professional commissions from the beauty industry. Clients have included Revlon, Wella and L'Oreal.

Member of fotofoto Gallery Member of SohoPhoto Gallery Chosen as one of Long Island Pulse Magazine’s V.I.P. Artists
Bob Leonard is a street photographer based in New York City and a member of the Soho Photo Gallery.

Susan Bowen lives in New York City and is mostly known for her overlapping multiple exposure panoramas, which she shoots with a plastic camera. In 2008 Susan completed a 48’ public art mural for a school in New Haven, Connecticut, and the previous year she created four murals for the Department of Transportation in Minnesota. In 2007 she was profiled in Photo Techniques and Light Leaks magazines, published in Light and Lens: Photography in the Digital Age, and received an award in the Pilsner Urquell International Photography/Lucie 2007 Awards. In 2006 and 2010 Susan had four images published in Plastic Cameras: Toying with Creativity, a book by Michelle Bates. Her 15 solo shows have been in New York, Las Vegas, Pittsburgh, Reno, Dayton, San Marino, Lubbock, Georgia, and Tennessee. Susan has been in over 175 group shows, including ones at the Safe-T, Nelson Hancock, and Sideshow galleries in Brooklyn, the Photographic Center NW in Seattle, Woman Made Gallery in Chicago, and the Center for Fine Art Photography in Fort Collins. She has been a finalist for public art projects in Brooklyn, Tampa, Gainesville, Iowa, Indianapolis, Kansas City, and Frisco, Texas. Susan's current projects include a series of digital images exploring the topics of people walking and various pictures of the ground. She is also a computer programmer by trade. Her work can be seen at www.susanbowenphoto.com and on Instagram @susanbowenfoto.

I began to take photography seriously when I was 14 years old. My uncle had given me his old Voigtlander Bellows Camera, which was the first camera I owned with a manual shutter speed and F-stop. My humble darkroom was in a basement closet. I can still remember how excited I was a few years later when I got my first enlarger, and could finally make something bigger than a contact print. In the intervening years I've developed a passion for making images. I've dabbled in painting, and do a good bit of sketching, but photography is where I spend the greater part of my creative energy. My work has appeared at the Soho Photo Gallery, Blue Door Gallery, Cottage Gallery, and The Pomona Arts Center.

My photography is inspired by the landscape and people of New York City. I primarily enjoy photographing people on the street going about their daily lives in the bustling urban environment that I call home. Whether it be Coney Island, Fifth Avenue or a Brooklyn neighborhood, finding and photographing an interesting situation, juxtaposed with a bit humor, is what I seek to accomplish. Before becoming a member/artist at Soho Photo, where I have had several solo shows, I exhibited for over twenty years in numerous solo and group shows. My work is included in numerous corporate and private collections, including Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer, and Bristol Meyers Squibb.

2016 • Soho Photo Gallery, New York, NY: Fade 2015 • Soho Photo Gallery, New York, NY: Abstracts • 2014 • • 2013 • The Big Picture: Month of Photography Denver (Curator: Mark Sink) Soho Photo Gallery, New York, NY: Parallel Photoville Brooklyn NY: Soho Photo Gallery, Picturing the Built Environment Grady Alexis Gallery, New York NY: I Have a Dream – 50 Years of Change (Curator: Andrea Arroyo) • Mamaroneck Artists Guild, Larchmont NY: 9th Open Juried Small Works Exhibition (Juror: Ann Von Stuelpnagel) • Soho Photo Gallery, New York, NY: Street Photography 2013 2012 • Powerhouse Arena, Brooklyn NY: Abandoned (Juror: Amy Arbus) • Viridian Artists, New York NY: 23 rd International Juried Exhibition (Juror: Chrissie Iles) • Mamaroneck Artists Guild, Larchmont NY: 8th Open Juried Small Works Exhibition (Juror: Neil Watson) • Red Filter Gallery, Lambertville NJ: A Monochrome Winter (Curator: Forrest Old) 2011 • 440 Gallery, Brooklyn NY: 7th Annual Small Works Show (Juror: Sara Mintz) • fotofoto gallery, Huntington NY: 7th National Photography Competition (Jurors: Dan Burkholder and Jill Skupin Burkholder) • Curate NYC 2011: Online Exhibition curated by Siona O'Connell • Umbrella Arts Gallery, New York NY: Dinner (Juror: Harvey Stein) 2010 • Curate NYC 2010: New York NY Affiliations: Soho Photo Gallery; International Center of Photography: Teaching Assistant (April - June 2011) | Publications: F-Stop Magazine
Peter Agron b.1948 in Saint Petersburg (Russia), living in US since 1975.

For over thirty years, Robert Kalman has been making formal, large format portraits of people he meets on the street. In addition to his large format portraiture, he has worked as a freelance editorial photographer for regional newspapers and magazines in the northeast. He has studied with photographic luminaries such as the late Arnold Newman, the late Mary Ellen Mark, Marie Cosindas, Judy Dater and Jeff Cowen. His work has taken him to across Europe and Latin America.
Among Robert’s published work: a book on interracial couples, and one on the Kuna of Panama, as well as several volumes of portraits made on the streets of New York and cities across Europe. His latest book is devoted to portraits of Nicaraguan villagers photographed twenty years apart.
Robert’s most recent work is a series of diptychs; formal street portraits shown along side descriptions that are handwritten by the sitter. These have been exhibited widely: In New York City at The Soho Photo Gallery and The Center for Photographic Art; in Poughkeepsie, NY at Barrett Art Center; in Portland, OR at Black Box Gallery; in Philadelphia at ONWARD Compé; in Fort Collins, CO at The Center for Fine Art Photography; and in Danbury, CT at Still River Editions.
In September 2016 Robert will exhibit I Am Here : The Lesbian Portraits, in Fort Lauderdale at the Stonewall Museum, and in December in New York at the Soho Photo Gallery.
Robert Kalman and his wife, Linda, live in the Mid-Hudson Valley region of New York.
